 While patriotism sounds nice, power always goes hand in hand with money based on national wealth, either existing, the industrial capability with markets to grow that wealth or military ability in invade and use the wealth of conquered countries. Following WW11, the US dominated world markets due to the fact that the industrialization geared up to win that war was easily convertible to civilian applications and world markets consisted of an industrially devastated Europe, Asia and Africa. 
 
 By the 1970s, Europe and Asia, Japan and China in particular, had regained their financial health and made inroads into the largest consumer market in the world, the US. The US had two later surges of prosperity, the '80s when Regan took advantage of the 1976 deregulation of oil and established the ME as our source of cheap oil, and the dot.com bubble, based on paper equity gains that proved to be non-existent. Looking at the 30-year decline of the US dollar, currently being accelerated by a massive imbalance of trade, US industrial dominance started fading after oil deregulation and, aside from those aforementioned two instances, IMO will not recover without an economic disaster to lower a standard of living currently being sustained by deficit public and consumer spending. Based on Iraq, we certainly don't have the military occupation capability to pillage the resources of other countries without a general draft and certainly don't have the competitive industrial capability to generate enough wealth to pay for that by picking off third tier nations such as Iraq one at a time. 
 
 Who next in line? Without a nuclear war, I'd have to say China. That's where world capital is going, and their intense internal planning, gained by sending their intellect to the best schools around the world for the past three decades, is making good use of that capital and formulating trade agreements (without military actions) to supply their lack of natural resources. Combined with their overall low standard of living, it's almost impossible for other nations to compete with their industrial output and exports are what create immense national wealth. 
 
 If Europe unites fast enough with those nations still affording opportunities for cheap labor and rapid modernization, enough niche markets can be developed to somewhat share a portion of China's vast potential consumer markets with domestic Chinese production. 
 
 According to most futurists, the US will eventually unite with Canada and the rest of the Americas, but I feel those will be survival efforts, not an effort for industrial dominance. We're already using the natural resources of those countries at a rate to where not much will be left for export purposes. 
 
 I still believe 9/11 and then Iraq were the first visible nails in our financial coffin. Spending half of one's operating budget on military and internal security, regardless of how they relate to a public debt/consumer driven GDP, is not sustainable with a declining tax base.
